TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit ColumnHeader extends System.ComponentModel.Component implements class System.ICloneable

Docs.summary: Displays a single column header in a control.

remarks.format:
## Remarks A column header is an item in a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> control that contains heading text. ColumnHeader objects can be added to a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> using the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.ColumnHeaderCollection.Add%2A> method of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.ColumnHeaderCollection> class. To add a group of columns to a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView>, you can use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.ColumnHeaderCollection.AddRange%2A> method of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.ColumnHeaderCollection> class. You can use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ColumnHeader.Index%2A> property of the ColumnHeader class to determine where the ColumnHeader is located in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.ColumnHeaderCollection>.
ColumnHeader provides the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ColumnHeader.Text%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ColumnHeader.TextAlign%2A> properties to set the text displayed in the control and the alignment of the text in the column header. To determine whether a ColumnHeader is associated with a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> control, you can reference the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ColumnHeader.ListView%2A> property. If you want to copy a ColumnHeader for use in another <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> control, you can use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ColumnHeader.Clone%2A> method.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates initializing a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> control. The example creates ColumnHeader objects and sets the column header's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ColumnHeader.Text%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ColumnHeader.TextAlign%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ColumnHeader.Width%2A> properties. The example also adds items and subitems to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView>. To run this example paste the following code in a form and call the `PopulateListView` method from the form's constructor or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form.Load> event handler.
[!code-cpp[System.Windows.Forms.ListViewAndPictureBox#1](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/t-system.windows.forms.c_3_1.cpp)] [!code-cs[System.Windows.Forms.ListViewAndPictureBox#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/t-system.windows.forms.c_3_1.cs)] [!code-vb[System.Windows.Forms.ListViewAndPictureBox#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/t-system.windows.forms.c_3_1.vb)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance void AutoResize(valuetype System.Windows.Forms.ColumnHeaderAutoResizeStyle headerAutoResize) cil managed

Docs.summary: Resizes the width of the column as indicated by the resize style.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Calling the AutoResize method is only effective once the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> and containing <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form> have been constructed, and the column is populated with items. If new items are added to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView>, the column will not resize unless AutoResize is called again.

Docs.exception: A value other than is passed to the AutoResize method when the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.View%2A> property is a value other than .

remarks.format: ## Remarks You can use this method to copy existing <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ColumnHeader> objects from an existing <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> control for use in other <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> controls.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the display order of the column relative to the currently displayed columns.
Docs.value: The display order of the column, relative to the currently displayed columns.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig virtual instance void Dispose(bool disposing) cil managed

Docs.param: to release both managed and unmanaged resources; to release only unmanaged resources.
Docs.summary: Disposes of the resources (other than memory) used by the .

remarks.format:
## Remarks Call Dispose when you are finished using the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ColumnHeader>. The Dispose method leaves the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ColumnHeader> in an unusable state. After calling Dispose, you must release all references to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ColumnHeader> so the memory it was occupying can be reclaimed by garbage collection.
> [!NOTE] > Always call Dispose before you release your last reference to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ColumnHeader>. Otherwise, the resources the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ColumnHeader> is using will not be freed until garbage collection calls the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ColumnHeader> object's destructor.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the index of the image displayed in the .
Docs.value: The index of the image displayed in the .

remarks.format:
## Remarks The ImageIndex property refers to the index of an image specified by the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.SmallImageList%2A> property of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> that contains the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ColumnHeader>. The ImageIndex property returns -1 if there is no <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.SmallImageList%2A> set on the containing <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView>. The image displayed in a column is typically used to indicate the state of items in the column.
<xref:System.Windows.Forms.ColumnHeader.ImageKey%2A> and ImageIndex are mutually exclusive, meaning if one is set, the other is set to an invalid value and ignored.
The image associated with a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ColumnHeader> is typically used to indicate the state information. If you set the ImageIndex to a value greater than the index of the last item in the associated image list, ImageIndex will be set to the index of the last item in the image list.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the key of the image displayed in the column.
Docs.value: The key of the image displayed in the column.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The ImageKey and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ColumnHeader.ImageIndex%2A> properties are mutually exclusive, meaning if one is set, the other is set to an invalid value and ignored.
If ImageKey is set to an invalid value, an image will not be displayed, and an exception will not be thrown.
The image associated with a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ColumnHeader> is typically used to indicate the state information.

Docs.summary: Gets the image list associated with the .

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ColumnHeader> returns the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.SmallImageList%2A> property for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> that contains the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ColumnHeader>.

Docs.summary: Gets the location with the control's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.ColumnHeaderCollection> of this column.
Docs.value: The zero-based index of the column header within the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.ColumnHeaderCollection> of the control it is contained in.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The value of this property does not necessarily correspond to the current visual position of the column header within the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView>. This can be due to the user reordering the column headers at run time (when the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.AllowColumnReorder%2A> property is set to `true`). If the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ColumnHeader> is not contained within a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> control this property returns a value of -1.

Docs.summary: Gets the control the is located in.
Docs.value: A control that represents the control that contains the .

remarks.format: ## Remarks You can use this property to determine which <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> control a specific <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ColumnHeader> object is associated with.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the name of the .
Gets or sets an object that contains data to associate with the .
Docs.value: An <xref:System.Object> that contains data to associate with the .

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the text displayed in the column header.
Docs.value: The text displayed in the column header.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code example demonstrates initializing a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> control. The example creates <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ColumnHeader> objects and sets the column header's Text, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ColumnHeader.TextAlign%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ColumnHeader.Width%2A> properties. The example also adds items and subitems to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView>. To run this example paste the following code in a form and call the `PopulateListView` method from the form's constructor or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form.Load> event handler.
[!code-cpp[System.Windows.Forms.ListViewAndPictureBox#1](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/p-system.windows.forms.c_54_1.cpp)] [!code-cs[System.Windows.Forms.ListViewAndPictureBox#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.windows.forms.c_54_1.cs)] [!code-vb[System.Windows.Forms.ListViewAndPictureBox#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.windows.forms.c_54_1.vb)]

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the horizontal alignment of the text displayed in the .
Docs.value: One of the values. The default is .

remarks.format:
## Remarks You can use this property to provide different text alignment settings for the text displayed in each <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ColumnHeader>.
> [!NOTE] > Due to a limitation in the underlying control, this property has no effect on the first column in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> control, which is always aligned to the left. To work around this limitation in [!INCLUDE[dnprdnext](~/add/includes/dnprdnext-md.md)], you can handle the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.DrawColumnHeader?displayProperty=fullName> event and paint the column header yourself.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates initializing a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> control. The example creates <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ColumnHeader> objects and sets the column header's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ColumnHeader.Text%2A>, TextAlign and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ColumnHeader.Width%2A> properties. The example also adds items and subitems to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView>. To run this example paste the following code in a form and call the `PopulateListView` method from the form's constructor or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form.Load> event handler.

Docs.summary: Returns a <xref:System.String> containing the name of the , if any. This method should not be overridden.
Docs.returns: A <xref:System.String> containing the name of the , if any, or if the is unnamed.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the width of the column.
Docs.value: The width of the column, in pixels.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This property enables you to set the Width of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ColumnHeader>. The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ColumnHeader> can be set to adjust at run time to the column contents or heading. To adjust the width of the longest item in the column, set the Width property to -1. To autosize to the width of the column heading, set the Width property to -2.
> [!NOTE] > Unexpected behavior can result when the combined width of all columns exceeds 32,768 pixels.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates initializing a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> control. The example creates <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ColumnHeader> objects and sets the column header's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ColumnHeader.Text%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ColumnHeader.TextAlign%2A> and Width properties. The example also adds items and subitems to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView>. To run this example paste the following code in a form and call the `PopulateListView` method from the form's constructor or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form.Load> event handler.
